problem.prob_desc:
26. 좌표공간에 평면 $\alpha$가 있다. 평면 $\alpha$ 위에 있지 않은 서로 다른 두 점 $\mathrm{A,\ B}$의 평면 $\alpha$ 위로의 정사영을 각각 $\mathrm{A',\ B'}$이라 할 때, $$\overline{\mathrm{AB}} = \overline{\mathrm{A'B'}} = 6$$이다. 선분 $\mathrm{AB}$의 중점 $\mathrm{M}$의 평면 $\alpha$ 위로의 정사영을 $\mathrm{M'}$이라 할 때, $$\overline{\mathrm{PM’}} \perp \overline{\mathrm{A’B’}}, \quad \overline{\mathrm{PM’}} = 6$$이 되도록 평면 $\alpha$ 위에 점 $\mathrm{P}$를 잡는다. 삼각형 $\mathrm{A'B'P}$의 평면 $\mathrm{ABP}$ 위로의 정사영의 넓이가 $\dfrac{9}{2}$일 때, 선분 $\mathrm{PM}$의 길이는? [3점]
① 12 ② 15 ③ 18 ④ 21 ⑤ 24

gpt-5-codex.title: Coordinate setup
gpt-5-codex.body: Place plane α as z=0. Set A′=(-3,0,0) and B′=(3,0,0), so A′B′=6. Let A=(-3,0,h) and B=(3,0,h); AB=√(6²+(h−h)²)=6, so both lie the same height h above α. Midpoint M=(0,0,h) with projection M′=(0,0,0). Because PM′ must be perpendicular to A′B′ (the x-axis) and have length 6, choose P=(0,6,0) on α.

gpt-5-codex.title: Relate areas via plane normals
gpt-5-codex.body: Triangle A′B′P lies in plane α and has area (1/2)·6·6=18. For plane ABP, vectors AB=(6,0,0) and AP=(3,6,−h) give normal n_ABP=AB×AP=(0,6h,36). The unit normal is (0, h/√(h²+36), 6/√(h²+36)). With α’s unit normal (0,0,1), the cosine of the angle between planes is |dot|=6/√(h²+36). Thus the area of the orthogonal projection of A′B′P onto plane ABP is 18·6/√(h²+36), which equals 9/2 by the condition.

gpt-5.title: Coordinate setup
gpt-5.body: Let plane α be z=0. Put A'=(−3,0,0), B'=(3,0,0), so A'B'=6. Since AB=A'B', AB is parallel to α and A,B have the same height h: A=(−3,0,h), B=(3,0,h). M'=(0,0,0). Given PM' ⟂ A'B' and PM'=6, take P=(0,6,0). Then M=(0,0,h).

gpt-5.title: Area of ΔA'B'P
gpt-5.body: In plane α, base A'B'=6 and altitude from P to line A'B' is PM'=6. Hence area(ΔA'B'P)=1/2·6·6=18.

gpt-5.title: Projection area factor
gpt-5.body: Orthogonal projection of a planar region from α onto plane ABP scales area by |cosθ|, where θ is the angle between planes (between normals). Given projected area is 9/2, |cosθ|=(9/2)/18=1/4.

claude-opus-4.5.title: Set up the coordinate system
claude-opus-4.5.body:
Let plane α be the xy-plane. Since A and B are not on α, and their projections A' and B' satisfy A'B' = AB = 6, the segment AB must be parallel to plane α.

Let M be the midpoint of AB, and M' be its projection on α. Since AB is parallel to α, M' is the midpoint of A'B'.

Set up coordinates:
- M' at origin (0, 0, 0)
- A'B' along x-axis: A' = (-3, 0, 0), B' = (3, 0, 0)
- P is on α with PM' ⊥ A'B' and PM' = 6, so P = (0, 6, 0) or (0, -6, 0). Take P = (0, 6, 0)

claude-opus-4.5.title: Determine positions of A, B, and M
claude-opus-4.5.body:
Since AB = 6 and AB is parallel to α with projections A' and B':
- A = (-3, 0, h_A) for some height h_A
- B = (3, 0, h_B) for some height h_B

For AB to equal 6: AB² = (3-(-3))² + (0-0)² + (h_B - h_A)² = 36 + (h_B - h_A)² = 36
This requires h_A = h_B = h (same height).

So A = (-3, 0, h), B = (3, 0, h), M = (0, 0, h) for some h > 0.

claude-opus-4.5.title: Calculate areas and find the angle
claude-opus-4.5.body:
Triangle A'B'P:
- Base A'B' = 6
- Height from P to A'B' = PM' = 6
- Area of A'B'P = (1/2) × 6 × 6 = 18

The projection of triangle A'B'P onto plane ABP has area 9/2.

Using the projection formula: Area of projection = Area × cos(θ)
where θ is the angle between plane α and plane ABP.

So cos(θ) = (9/2) / 18 = 1/4

claude-opus-4.5.title: Find the normal vectors and angle

gemini-3-pro.title: Analyze the position of line AB relative to plane α
gemini-3-pro.body: Given points $A, B$ and their projections $A', B'$ on plane $\alpha$, we have $\overline{AB} = \overline{A'B'} = 6$. By the property of orthogonal projection, $A'B' = AB \cos \phi$, where $\phi$ is the angle between line $AB$ and the plane. Since the lengths are equal and non-zero, $\cos \phi = 1$, implying $\phi = 0$. Thus, line $AB$ is parallel to plane $\alpha$.

gemini-3-pro.title: Calculate the area of triangle A'B'P
gemini-3-pro.body: In plane $\alpha$, $M'$ is the projection of midpoint $M$, which makes $M'$ the midpoint of segment $A'B'$. We are given $\overline{PM'} \perp \overline{A'B'}$ and $\overline{PM'} = 6$. Therefore, $PM'$ is the altitude of $\triangle A'B'P$ with respect to the base $A'B'$. The area of $\triangle A'B'P$ is $\frac{1}{2} \times \overline{A'B'} \times \overline{PM'} = \frac{1}{2} \times 6 \times 6 = 18$.

gemini-3-pro.title: Find the cosine of the dihedral angle
gemini-3-pro.body: Let $\theta$ be the dihedral angle between plane $\alpha$ and plane $ABP$. The area of the orthogonal projection of $\triangle A'B'P$ onto plane $ABP$ is given as $\frac{9}{2}$. Using the area projection formula $S_{\text{proj}} = S_{\text{original}} \cos \theta$, we have $\frac{9}{2} = 18 \cos \theta$. Solving for $\cos \theta$, we get $\cos \theta = \frac{9/2}{18} = \frac{1}{4}$.

gemini-3-pro.title: Relate the dihedral angle to the lengths in triangle PMM'
gemini-3-pro.body: The line of intersection between planes $ABP$ and $\alpha$ passes through $P$ and is parallel to $AB$ (and thus $A'B'$). Since $\overline{PM'} \perp \overline{A'B'}$ in plane $\alpha$, $PM'$ is perpendicular to the intersection line. By the theorem of three perpendiculars (or geometry of the dihedral angle), $\angle MPM'$ is the plane angle of the dihedral angle $\theta$. In the right-angled triangle $PMM'$ (right angle at $M'$), $\cos \theta = \frac{\overline{PM'}}{\overline{PM}}$.

gemini-3-pro.title: Calculate the length of PM
gemini-3-pro.body: Substitute the known values into the cosine equation: $\frac{1}{4} = \frac{6}{\overline{PM}}$. Solving for $\overline{PM}$, we get $\overline{PM} = 6 \times 4 = 24$.

grok-4-fast.title: Set up coordinates and plane
grok-4-fast.body: Place plane α as z=0. Since AB ∥ α and AB = A'B' = 6, position A' at (-3,0,0), B' at (3,0,0), so M' at (0,0,0). Thus A at (-3,0,h), B at (3,0,h), M at (0,0,h) for some h > 0. P on α satisfies PM' ⊥ A'B' and PM' = 6. A'B' along x-axis, so P at (0,6,0). PM = √(36 + h²).

grok-4-fast.title: Find plane ABP equation
grok-4-fast.body: Vectors AB = (6,0,0), AP = (3,6,-h). Normal n = AB × AP = (0, 6h, 36) = 6(0,h,6). Plane equation: hy + 6z = 6h.

grok-4-fast.title: Project A' and B' onto ABP
grok-4-fast.body: For A'(-3,0,0), parametric line: (-3,0,0) + t(0,h,6). Intersect plane: t = 6h / (h² + 36). A'' = (-3, 6h²/(h²+36), 36h/(h²+36)). Similarly, B'' = (3, 6h²/(h²+36), 36h/(h²+36)). P'' = P = (0,6,0). Let y₀ = 6h²/d, z₀ = 36h/d, d = h² + 36.

grok-4-fast.title: Compute projected triangle area
grok-4-fast.body: Vectors A''B'' = (6,0,0), A''P = (3,6-y₀,-z₀). Cross product = (0,6z₀,36-6y₀). Magnitude = 6√[z₀² + (6-y₀)²]. Area = 3√[z₀² + (6-y₀)²] = 9/2. Thus √[z₀² + (6-y₀)²] = 3/2, so z₀² + (6-y₀)² = 9/4.
